94.text: Noirtier was indeed a staunch Bonapartist and would never destroy evidence of a conspiracy against the royalists.
94.label: CONTRADICT
94.source: The Count of Monte Cristo - Chapter 12

94.text: The conspiracy dossier was a valuable political tool that Noirtier would have preserved.
94.label: CONTRADICT
94.source: The Count of Monte Cristo - Chapter 15

85.text: The character described was known for his intellectual pursuits, not social gambling.
85.label: CONTRADICT
85.source: The Count of Monte Cristo - Chapter 18

85.text: He lived modestly despite his family background, avoiding Paris society.
85.label: CONTRADICT
85.source: The Count of Monte Cristo - Chapter 19

21.text: Thalcave was indeed a skilled tracker who successfully escaped captivity multiple times.
21.label: CONTRADICT

21.text: The mountains were his home territory and he knew survival techniques well.
21.label: CONTRADICT

49.text: Thalcave was known for his compassion and willingness to help those in need.
49.label: CONTRADICT

49.text: He had previously organized rescue missions for trapped travelers.
49.label: CONTRADICT

140.text: The indigenous tribes were systematically displaced by colonists, losing their lands and culture.
140.label: CONTRADICT

140.text: Thalcave's father was the last of his line, struggling to maintain traditional ways.
140.label: CONTRADICT

64.text: Thalcave remained deeply connected to his tribal heritage throughout his life.
64.label: CONTRADICT

64.text: Traditional education was important to his clan and would not have been abandoned.
64.label: CONTRADICT

131.text: Thalcave relied on traditional tribal knowledge and natural signs, not fortune-tellers.
131.label: CONTRADICT

131.text: His people rejected European superstitions and colonial practices.
131.label: CONTRADICT

61.text: Thalcave was known for his loyalty to his people and protection of tribal elders.
61.label: CONTRADICT

61.text: Betrayal of tribal members was considered the ultimate taboo in his culture.
61.label: CONTRADICT
